p.seg: Therefore it is said:
《Foundation of the Dao, First》
It is transmitted that:
“Heaven gives birth to the myriad things,
the earth nourishes them,
and the sage completes them.”
Meritorious deeds and virtue combine,
and the methods of the Dao are produced.
Spreading the sun and moon,
arranging the stars and constellations,
ordering the four seasons,
harmonizing yin and yang,
distributing qi to govern nature,
sequentially establishing the five elements,
spring generates, summer grows,
autumn harvests, winter stores,
yang generates thunder and lightning,
yin forms snow and frost,
nurturing all living things,
one flourishes, one perishes,
moistening them with wind and rain,
baking them with sunlight,
warming them with seasonal influences,
bringing down falling frost upon them,
positioning them with the myriad stars,
controlling them with the Dipper and balance,
Enveloping it with the six directions (the universe),
Netting it with guiding principles,
Rectifying it with calamities and changes,
Announcing to it with auspicious omens,
Stirring it with life and death,
Enlighening it with written works.
Therefore, what is in the heavens can be seen,
What is on the earth can be measured,
What is in objects can be recorded,
What is in people can be judged.
Therefore, the earth demarcates the Five Peaks,
Charts the Four Rivers,
Regulates the ponds and marshes,
Connects the waters and springs,
Plants things and nourishes kinds,
Envelops and propagates the myriad roots,
Exposes forms and nourishes essences,
In order to establish the living beings,
Not violating the seasons of Heaven,
Not depriving the nature of things,
Not concealing its feelings,
Not hiding its deceptions.
Therefore, those who know Heaven look up to observe the celestial patterns,
Those who know Earth bend down to examine the terrestrial patterns,
Those that walk and breathe,
The kind of crawling, flying, and wriggling,
Those that live in water and move on land,
whose roots are fixed and leaves grow,
are made to quiet their minds and secure their nature,
for Heaven and Earth support each other,
and their energies resonate to bring them into being.
Thereupon the ancient sages looked up to observe the celestial patterns,
and bowed down to examine the terrestrial forms,
mapping the heavens and earth,
in order to establish the way of humanity.
The people then began to awaken,
knowing there was a bond of affection between father and son,
righteousness between ruler and subject,
the way of husband and wife,
and the proper order between elder and younger.
Then the hundred officials were established,
and the way of the king was born.
The common people ate meat and drank blood,
and wore skins and furs;
until Shennong,
believing that crawling insects and running beasts
were difficult to use to nourish the people,
sought edible things,
tasting the fruits of hundreds of plants,
examining their sour and bitter flavors,
and teaching the people to eat the five grains.
The people of the world
lived in the wilderness, dwelling in caves,
without houses or dwellings.
They shared the same territory as birds and beasts.
Thereupon, the Yellow Emperor felled trees and constructed timber,
building palaces and houses,
with upper beams and lower eaves,
to avoid wind and rain.
The people knew to dwell in houses and eat grain,
but did not understand labor and effort.
Then, Hou Ji demarcated boundaries,
and drew boundary lines,
to divide the land according to its suitability;
he cultivated the soil and planted grain,
to nourish the people;
he planted mulberry and hemp,
producing silk and flax,
to cover their bodies.
At this time,
the Four Rivers were not yet connected,
and floods caused harm.
Yu then breached the Yangtze and dredged the Yellow River,
connecting them to the Four Rivers,
and leading them to the sea.
Large and small drew from each other,
high and low received from each other,
the hundred rivers flowed smoothly,
Each returned to their proper place,
and then the people were able to leave the high and dangerous places
and live on level ground.
Rivers and valleys intersected,
civilization had not yet spread,
the nine provinces were isolated,
and there were no boats or carts
to cross deep waters and reach distant places.
Therefore, Xi Zhong bent wood to make wheels,
and straightened wood to make shafts,
harnessing horses and yoking oxen,
using floating boats and oars,
to replace human labor.
Smelting metal, carving wood, dividing seedlings, and burning fields to prepare tools and implements,
thus the people knew about weight and value,
loved profit and hated difficulty,
avoided labor and sought ease.
Therefore, Gao Yao established prisons and created punishments,
offering rewards and setting penalties,
distinguishing right from wrong,
clarifying good and evil,
investigating treachery and wickedness,
and eliminating disorder and chaos.
The people knew to fear the law,
but had no sense of propriety or righteousness.
Thereupon, the Sage of the Middle Ages established the teachings of the Biyong, Xiang, and Xu,
in order to rectify the standards of superiors and inferiors,
to clarify the proper relationship between father and son, and the righteousness between ruler and subject,
so that the strong would not oppress the weak, and the many would not tyrannize the few,
to abandon greedy and base hearts,
and to promote pure and upright conduct.
If ritual and righteousness are not practiced,
the fundamental principles will not be established,
and later generations will decline and fall;
therefore, the Later Sages established the *Five Classics*,
clarified the *Six Arts*,
continuing the mandate of Heaven and regulating the Earth,
exploring matters to their fullest extent and examining subtle details,
investigating the origins of feelings and establishing fundamental principles,
in order to order human relationships,
taking Heaven and Earth as their model,
compiling and composing chapters,
bequeathing them to future generations,
extending their influence even to birds and beasts,
in order to correct decline and disorder,
a plan uniting Heaven and humanity,
encompassing the source of the Way completely,
so that the wise could understand its meaning,
and all artisans could exhaust their skills.
Then they harmonized them with the sounds of wind, string, and bamboo instruments,
and established the music of bells, drums, songs, and dances,
in order to regulate extravagance,
to rectify customs,
To penetrate literature and refinement.
Later generations became licentious and perverse,
adding to it the music of Zheng and Wei;
the people abandoned fundamentals and pursued trivialities,
artifice and skill emerged unrestrained,
intentions differing from each other,
then they added elaborate carvings and engravings,
transmitting and applying glue, lacquer, cinnabar, azure, dark yellow, and precious and rare colors,
to exhaust the pleasures of the ear and eye,
and exhaust the skill of artisans.
Now, donkeys, mules, camels,
rhinoceroses, elephants, hawksbill turtles,
amber, coral,
kingfisher feathers, pearls, and jade,
growing in mountains and hidden in water,
choose their place to dwell;
clean, clear, bright,
moist and wet,
ground without becoming thin,
dyed without becoming black,
born from the breath of heaven,
governed by spiritual beings,
secluded, tranquil, pure,
floating and sinking with the divine,
all exert their strength to be useful,
and exhaust their nature to become vessels.
Therefore, it is said,
the sage completes it.
It is how he can unify all things, comprehend change,
govern emotions and nature,
and manifest benevolence and righteousness.
For a person (of virtue) is broad, vast, and great,
extensive, subtle, and profound,
attaching the distant and pacifying the near,
embracing and attracting all nations.
Therefore, the sage cherishes benevolence and relies on righteousness,
discerning clearly the minute and subtle,
measuring heaven and earth.
Being in danger but not collapsing,
being at ease but not falling into disorder,
this is what benevolence and righteousness govern.
Practicing it towards close relatives, even those who are distant are pleased;
cultivating it within the inner chambers, and fame and reputation spread abroad.
Therefore, benevolence has nothing hidden that is not revealed,
nothing obscure that is not made manifest.
Yu Shun's filial piety towards his parents
shone brightly in heaven and earth.
Bo Yi and Shu Qi starved on Shouyang Mountain,
but their meritorious virtue was passed down through ten thousand generations.
The Grand Duke (Jiang Ziya) rose from commoner to the position of Three Dukes,
and for generations, his descendants enjoyed the title of a thousand chariots.
Zhi Bo relied on his authority and strength,
annexing the three Jin states, but then perished.
Therefore, the superior man grasps the Dao to govern,
relies on virtue to act,
sits upon the mat of benevolence,
leans on the staff of righteousness to become strong,
being empty, non-existent and silent,
reaching all movements without measure.
Therefore, in regulating affairs, he takes advantage of the short and makes movements grow longer,
using the compass to make circles,
using the square to create squares.
Sages become kings of the world,
virtuous men establish meritorious deeds.
Tang raised up Yi Yin,
the Zhou employed Ren Lü Wang.
Their actions accord with Heaven and Earth,
their virtue matches Yin and Yang.
They receive the will of Heaven to punish evil,
overcome violence and eliminate calamity.
They use their Qi to nourish things,
their clear ◇ establishing light.
Their ears hear the eight limits,
their eyes see the four directions.
Loyalty advances, slander retreats,
uprightness stands, evil perishes.
The Dao is practiced, wickedness stops,
and cannot be simultaneously displayed.
◇ originates from principle,
blocking the gradual, eliminating the bud.
Now, plans that do not incorporate both benevolence and righteousness will inevitably fail in the end.
Planting without firm roots but building a high foundation will inevitably collapse in the end.
Therefore, the sage prevents chaos by using classics and arts,
and the craftsman corrects curves with plumb lines and compasses.
When virtue flourishes, authority expands;
when power flourishes, arrogance increases.
Duke Huan of Qi valued virtue to achieve hegemony,
while the Second Emperor of Qin valued punishment and perished.
Therefore, cruel actions accumulate resentment,
and spreading virtue promotes success.
The people attach themselves through virtue,
relatives are close through benevolence,
husband and wife unite through righteousness,
friends trust each other through righteousness,
ruler and ministers are ordered through righteousness,
and all officials carry out their duties through righteousness.
Zeng and Min achieved great filial piety through benevolence,
and Bo Ji established utmost chastity through righteousness.
Those who defend the state are solidified through benevolence,
and those who assist the ruler do not falter through righteousness.
The ruler governs through benevolence,
and the ministers maintain peace through righteousness.
The villages are harmonious through benevolence,
and the court is proper through righteousness.
Beautiful women display their conduct through chastity,
and heroes make their names known through righteousness.
The Yang energy is generated through benevolence,
Yin Jie surrendered through righteousness;
The "Deer Cry" seeks its companions through benevolence;
"Guan Ju" calls out to its male through righteousness;
The *Spring and Autumn Annals* uses benevolence and righteousness to praise and condemn;
The *Book of Poetry* regards benevolence and righteousness as the basis for survival and destruction;
*Qian* (Heaven) and *Kun* (Earth) combine through benevolence and harmony;
The *Eight Trigrams* are passed down through righteousness;
The *Book of Documents* uses benevolence to describe the nine familial relations;
The relationship between ruler and subject establishes loyalty through righteousness;
The *Book of Rites* uses benevolence to fulfill propriety to the utmost;
Music follows ritual in its advancement and decline.
Benevolence is the guiding principle of the Way;
Righteousness is the learning of the sages.
Those who study it become enlightened;
Those who lose it become confused;
Those who turn their backs on it perish.
Exert your strength and take your place;
Establish merit through righteousness;
When armies march and form ranks,
Virtue and benevolence are the foundation of strength;
Reliance on righteousness leads to power.
Regulate your breath and nourish your nature;
The benevolent live long lives.
Differentiate talent and rank virtue;
The righteous have upright conduct.
Gentlemen praise each other through righteousness;
Petty men deceive each other with profit;
The foolish use force to create chaos;
the wise use righteousness to govern.
The *Guliang Zhuan* says:
"The benevolent govern their relatives with benevolence,
the righteous benefit the honored with righteousness.
For ten thousand generations there will be no chaos;
this is what benevolence and righteousness govern."
*The Second Chapter: Techniques and Affairs*
He who speaks well of the ancients applies it to the present;
he who can describe the distant examines it in the near.
Therefore, he who speaks of affairs above recounts the merits of the Five Emperors,
and reflects upon them in himself;
below, he lists the failures of Jie and Zhou,
and warns himself against them.
Then his virtue can match the sun and moon,
his conduct can be in harmony with the spirits,
he can ascend high and reach far,
understand the obscure and penetrate the darkness,
hear the voiceless,
see the formless.
The people of the world do not see its omens,
do not know its true nature.
Examine and correct the origins and ends of the *Five Classics*,
the authenticity of morality and virtue;
after (you) understand its meaning,
(you) will not see its people.
The common people consider things passed down from ancient times as important,
and regard the works of modern authors as insignificant.
They are indifferent to what they see,
content with what they hear,
misled by outward appearances,
and miss the true essence of things.
Sages do not value scarcity,
but the common people despise abundance.
The five grains nourish life,
yet they are discarded on the ground.
Pearls and jade are useless,
yet they are treasured on the body.
Sages do not use pearls and jade to treasure their bodies.
Therefore, Shun discarded gold on the precipitous mountains,
and threw pearls and jade into the depths of the Five Lakes,
intending to block desires for excessive indulgence
and cut off feelings for the extraordinary and strange.
The Way, if near, does not necessarily originate from antiquity;
one should take what is most essential and effective.
The *Spring and Autumn Annals* does not go back to the Five Emperors,
nor does it extend to the Three Kings.
It narrates the minor virtues of Duke Huan of Qi and Duke Wen of Jin,
and the twelve dukes of Lu.
Even now, its principles of governance
are sufficient to understand the effects of success and failure.
Why is it necessary to go back to the Three Kings?
Therefore, what the ancients practiced
It is also the same as the present world.
Those who establish affairs do not depart from morality,
Those who tune strings do not lose the proper notes,
The way of Heaven regulates the four seasons,
The way of man governs the five constant virtues,
The Duke of Zhou and Yao and Shun were in accord with auspicious signs,
The Second Emperor and Jie and Zhou experienced the same disasters.
King Wen was born in the Eastern Yi,
Da Yu came from the Western Qiang,
Though times differ and locations are far apart,
The principles align and the standards are the same.
Therefore, sages and worthies accord with the Way,
The foolish are the same as disasters,
Those who cherish virtue should be rewarded with blessings,
Those who embrace evil will be repaid with misfortune,
Those with shallow virtue are in a precarious position,
Those who abandon the Way will perish,
The law is unchanging for ten thousand generations,
The fundamental principles are the same throughout ancient and modern times.
Therefore, good horses are not only the steeds of Qi Ji,
Sharp swords are not only those of Gan Jiang,
Beautiful women are not only Xi Shi,
Loyal ministers are not only Lü Wang.
If there is a horse but no Wang Liang to drive it,
If there is a sword but no sharpening,
If there is a woman but no fragrant adornments,
If a scholar does not encounter King Wen,
the accumulation of his Daoist arts cannot be released,
and a beautiful jade is stored in a box and deeply hidden.
Therefore, those who embrace the Dao need an era,
and those who hold to simplicity await a craftsman.
The Dao is established for the wise,
a horse is good for a charioteer,
the worthy are employed by the sages,
eloquence allows the wise to communicate,
books are transmitted by those who understand them,
and matters are made clear by those who see them.
Therefore, those who regulate affairs follow their principles,
and those who take medicine rely on its efficacy.
Books do not necessarily originate from the school of Confucius,
and medicines do not necessarily come from the prescriptions of Bian Que.
That which is fitting is good,
and can be taken as a law,
and should be pragmatically implemented according to the times.
Thus, if the inherent nature is stored within people,
then the vital energy reaches Heaven.
From the minute to the vast,
from lower learning to higher attainment,
affairs follow each other according to category,
and sounds respond to each other with harmony.
When the Dao is chanted, virtue harmonizes;
when benevolence is established, righteousness arises.
The king practices it in the court,
A common man working in the fields,
those who treat the branch should regulate the root,
those who straighten a shadow should correct its form,
nourish the root and the branches and leaves will flourish,
when ambition is regulated, then the Way will be achieved.
Therefore, those who seek afar must not lose sight of the near,
those who treat the shadow must not forget the form,
when the superior is enlightened, then the inferior will be pure,
when the ruler is sage, then the ministers will be loyal.
Some plan for the distant and lose the near,
some find the Way blocked and the road ends.
Ji Sun coveted the land of Zhuanyu,
and rebellion arose within the walls of Xiao.
Thus, those who advance and seize must not fail to consider the difficulties,
those who plan affairs must not fail to be utterly loyal;
therefore, when punishments are established, then virtue dissipates,
when flatterers are employed, then loyalty perishes.
The *Book of Poetry* says:
"Correct your heart,
to cherish all the states."
It speaks of one heart transforming the world,
and ◇◇ the state is governed,
this is what it means.
*Assisting Governance, Chapter Three*
Those who dwell in high places must not allow themselves to be insecure,
those who tread on danger must not allow their staff to be unsteady.
If one is insecure in a high place, then they will fall,
If a walking stick is not firm, one will fall.
Therefore, when a sage dwells in a high position,
he makes benevolence and righteousness his nest.
When facing danger and walking on precarious ground,
he takes the virtuous and sage as his walking stick.
Thus, he is high and does not fall,
in danger and does not collapse.
In the past,
Yao made benevolence and righteousness his nest,
Shun took Yu, Ji, and Qi as his walking sticks.
Therefore, he was high and even more secure,
moved and was even more firm.
He resided in a high and safe position,
carried the respect of overcoming and yielding,
his virtue matched Heaven and Earth,
his light covered the four directions,
his merit was bequeathed to infinity,
his name was passed on to immortality,
this was because he had secured his nest,
and his walking stick was made of the right material.
Qin took punishments and penalties as its nest,
therefore it suffered the calamity of an overturned nest and broken eggs.
It took Zhao Gao and Li Si as its walking sticks,
therefore it suffered the disaster of collapse, falling, and injury.
Why?
Because those relied upon were unsuitable.
Therefore, those who lean on sages become emperors,
Relying on the worthy leads to kingly rule;
relying on the benevolent leads to hegemony;
relying on the righteous leads to strength;
relying on slanderers leads to destruction;
relying on thieves leads to ruin.
Therefore, those who embrace rigidity are soon broken;
those who uphold flexibility last long;
the hasty and impetuous meet with quick failure;
the deliberate and weighty achieve lasting existence;
those who prize valor are close to regret;
the gentle and generous act with ease and expansiveness;
those who harbor urgency and haste are bound to suffer loss;
the soft and yielding control the rigid and strong;
small cleverness cannot resist the great;
small eloquence cannot persuade the masses;
merchants are skilled in the profits of trade,
but are inferior to the steadfast and virtuous;
wicked ministers are fond of deceit and falsehood,
flattering themselves and covering up their faults,
but are incapable of fairness and impartiality,
concealing their clever tricks,
evading their responsibilities and achievements.
Therefore, the shortcomings of the wise
are not as good as the strengths of the foolish.
Duke Wen planted rice;
Zengzi drove sheep.
An inexperienced fortune-teller,
believing in superstition, loses the way.
Those who are overly discerning have things they cannot see;
those who are generous-minded, what is it that they cannot tolerate?
Those who are simple and honest are close to loyalty;
those who are skilled in flattery are close to ruin.
The gentleman distances himself from dazzling colors,
abandons clanging sounds,
cuts off sweet and pleasing tastes,
and thins out feelings of choking and vomiting.
The Way of Heaven controls the small with the large,
and overturns the light with the heavy.
Using the small to govern the large
disrupts order and offends integrity.
Slanderers resemble the virtuous,
and beautiful words resemble the truth.
Those who listen to them are confused,
and those who observe them are deluded.
Therefore, Su Qin was respected among the feudal lords,
and Shang Yang became prominent in Western Qin.
If the world lacks a wise and intelligent ruler,
who can distinguish their true forms?
Therefore, Yao banished Huan Dou,
and Confucius executed Shaozheng Mao.
Whatever is praised in sweet words,
there is nothing they will not be inclined to do.
Only Yao knew their reality,
Zhongni saw their true nature.
Therefore, those who offend sage kings are punished,
those who obstruct virtuous rulers are sentenced,
those who encounter ordinary kings are ennobled,
and those who encounter chaotic times are glorified.
Zheng Dan fled Qi and returned to Lu.
Qi gained a reputation for nine alliances,
but Lu suffered the shame of losing its opportunity.
To possess a state of a thousand chariots
and trust in slanderous and fawning schemes
inevitably leads to destruction.
Thus, the *Book of Poetry* says:
"Slanderers know no bounds,
causing chaos in the four states."
When numerous evildoers unite in factions
to mislead the ruler,
the state is endangered and the people perish.
Is this not fitting?
*Non-Action, Chapter Four*
Of all the Dao, none is greater than non-action,
and of all actions, none is greater than cautious reverence.
Why do I say this?
In the past, when Yu Shun governed the world,
he played the five-stringed zither
and sang the *Southern Breeze* poem,
appearing as if he had no intention of governing the state
and as if he had no concern for the people.
However, the world was greatly governed.
The Duke of Zhou created rites and music,
sacrificed to Heaven and Earth,
made offerings to mountains and rivers.
Armies were not deployed,
punishments were set aside and laws hung unused.
And within the four seas,
tribute and offerings arrived,
the ruler of Yuechang
came to court with multiple interpreters.
Therefore, he who does nothing is the one who accomplishes things.
The First Emperor of Qin established penal laws,
instituted the punishment of dismemberment by chariots,
in order to restrain wickedness and evil.
He built the Great Wall on the borders,
to defend against the Hu and Yue peoples.
He conquered the large and swallowed the small,
his power shook the world.
Generals and commanders acted domineeringly,
in order to subjugate foreign lands.
Meng Tian suppressed rebellions abroad,
Li Si managed the laws at home.
The more affairs increased,
the more chaotic the world became.
The more laws multiplied, the more rampant wickedness became.
The more soldiers and horses were deployed, the more enemies there were.
It was not that Qin did not desire to govern well,
However, the reason for losing [the state]
is due to actions that violently offend the people
and the excessive use of punishments.
Therefore, the superior man values leniency and relaxation to maintain his person,
conducting himself with moderation and harmony to attract those distant;
the people fear his authority and follow his transformation,
cherish his virtue and return to his territory,
praise his governance and dare not violate his policies.
The people fear crime without being punished,
and are encouraged and pleased without being rewarded,
gradually immersed in morality,
and clothed in what moderation and harmony bring.
Now, laws are for punishing evil,
not for encouraging good.
Therefore, the filial piety of Zeng Shen and Min Ziqian,
and the integrity of Bo Yi and Shu Qi,
were they done out of fear of death?
They were brought about by education and transformation.
Therefore, it is said:
The people of Yao and Shun
could be enfeoffed from house to house,
the people of Jie and Zhou
could be executed from house to house.
Why?
Education and transformation made it so.
Therefore, land near the river is wet,
And the soil near the mountains that is dry
is affected by similar things nearby.
Therefore, mountains and rivers produce clouds and rain,
hills and mounds generate auspicious air,
the four great rivers flow eastward,
and the hundred streams never flow westward;
the small follows the large,
and the few follow the many.
Now, the capital of a king
and the ruler who faces south
are what the common people take as their models and laws.
Their actions and movements
must not deviate from these laws.
In the past,
King Xiang of Zhou was unable to serve his stepmother
and moved to live in Zheng,
and as a result, many people in the kingdom rebelled against their parents.
Emperor Qin Shihuang was arrogant, extravagant, and luxurious,
enjoyed building high terraces and pavilions,
and expanding palaces and chambers.
Consequently, the wealthy and powerful throughout the empire, when building houses and residences,
all imitated him,
setting up rooms and side doors,
preparing stables and storerooms,
refining the art of carving and engraving,
and collecting a wide variety of strange and wondrous colors,
thereby disrupting the established system.
Duke Huan of Qi was fond of women's beauty,
marrying his wife's aunts and sisters,
and within the state, many engaged in incestuous relations.
King Ping of Chu was extravagant and self-indulgent,
unable to control his subordinates,
or to regulate the people with virtue.
He increased the number of horses pulling his chariot to a hundred,
wanting to make the people of the world feel that his wealth and benefits were
clearly unattainable.
Consequently, the state of Chu became increasingly extravagant,
with no distinction between ruler and subject.
Therefore, the influence of superiors on their subordinates
is like the wind bending the grass.
If the ruler esteems martial prowess in court,
then farmers will repair armor and weapons in the fields.
Thus, the way a gentleman governs his inferiors is this:
if the people are extravagant,
then he should respond with frugality;
if they are arrogant and licentious,
then he should guide them with reason.
There has never been a case where the ruler is benevolent but the subjects are treacherous,
or where the ruler is righteous but the subjects are quarrelsome.
Therefore, Confucius said:
"To transform customs and change habits."
How could this be simply a matter of commanding one's household?
It must also be derived from oneself.
*Distinguishing Doubts, Chapter Five*
Now, when people undertake affairs, sometimes they do good deeds but are not praised for their goodness,
and sometimes they do bad deeds but are praised as good.
Why is this?
It is because those who observe are mistaken, and those who comment are in error.
Therefore, actions may conform to the world,
and words may please the ear.
This is to cater to the ruler's intentions,
and follow the ruler's will.
They hold to what is straight but deviate from the proper way,
harbor crookedness but conform to wickedness.
Taking advantage of situations of strength and weakness,
they devise strategies of manipulation.
Therefore, there are no words of opposition,
and no principles that do not agree.
Formerly, Duke Ai asked You Ruo, saying:
"The year is one of famine,
and resources are insufficient,
what should be done?"
You Ruo replied, saying:
"Why not use the che system?"
This means to diminish the ruler's revenue and return it to the people,
which offends the ear and does not accord with the ruler's intentions,
and so he was rejected and not employed.
This is what is meant by correcting one's actions without seeking to conform to the world.
How could You Ruo not have known how to cater to Duke Ai's intentions,
in order to benefit the state?
Therefore, a gentleman follows the correct way and proceeds,
Knowing that he would inevitably suffer humiliation, yet he did not avoid it.
Therefore, his actions dared not be carelessly compliant,
his words were not for the sake of careless acceptance,
even if he had no merit to the world,
his name was sufficient to be praised;
even if his words were not used by the state,
his words and deeds could be taken as a model.
Therefore, being different from worldly customs
causes one to be isolated from the multitude of scholars.
The crooked and perverse mutually carry each other along,
the bent and twisted mutually intertwine;
therefore, the upright cannot find room in between.
The flattering and fawning mutually support each other,
the slanderous mouths mutually praise each other.
What is the reason that there is no height they cannot reach,
no depth they cannot go to?
Because their cliques are numerous
and their words and speeches are harmonious and agreeable.
The condemnation and praise of the multitude
cause floating stones to sink and wooden objects to float.
The multitude of the wicked suppress each other,
taking the straight for the crooked.
Looking at it without careful examination,
they take white for black.
The different forms of crooked and straight,
the distinct colors of white and black,
What is under Heaven is easily seen,
yet eyes are misled and minds are confused.
Some cannot clearly distinguish right from wrong
because they are misled by the multitude of evils.
Take, for instance, the time of the Second Emperor of Qin.
Zhao Gao rode a deer and followed in attendance.
